186042967.review:
[h1] I HATE THE ODYSSEY UI!!! [/h1]

This is one of my most played games (I have several hundred hours before it came to steam), with most of my time spent in the Horizons era well before Odyssey which is an expansion I have not, and will never buy.

There is a lot I could say about this game, both positive and negative, nevertheless, what I have always seen as the greatest positive is the incredible foundation upon which all else is built. A core pillar of that being the beautiful, futuristic yet functional UI.

What compels me to make this review is my utter contempt for how unbelievably horrendous the new UI is in the current version of the game. It genuinely makes me angry every time I dock at a station and try and navigate the menus. The colours, the general layout, everything which has changed is just HIDEOUS. Not only is it godawful to look at, but it also makes it so, SO much harder to get immersed in the game like before.

Showing this game to a newcomer, in the past, I'd take pride in guiding them through the beautiful menus, that excitement would now be replaced by shame and feeble attempt to explain that it wasn't always like this.

Maybe it's just a personal problem, but every time I come back to spend an hour or so bounty hunting I end up leaving with a visceral disgust. 

I struggle to put into words how much I hate it - I mean I struggle to comprehend how any rational or passionate developer could actually be proud of the changes - so I end my rant here.

Let me end with this - the base game was so good to me that I would always be satisfied with it despite a complete lack of new content. That base game experience is now worsened to the point that I actively do not want to interact with it (yes that may seem extreme but the UI was a huge component for me), and thus I am here writing a negative review.

*Maybe it's possible to access an older version of the game, I haven't looked into it. Regardless, I think a negative review talking about the current state of the game is still relevant.

185898781.review:
This game... Is insane. This game is the sequel to Frontier Elite 2 which is the sequel to 1984s elite. In good Elite tradition this game is massive. And it is a good game. 

The game has very little handholding (get a docking module on your ships until you are comfortable manual docking) and you need to spend time with it get to know it. But the rewards are massive if you spend the time.

Out of the gate, you have the best space combat and best space exploration in any game. Planetary exploration is not as good as NMS but The space combat puts NMS in a corner. The game uses procedural generation and it works better than in NMS IMHO. It is a game that makes you go "how the hell have I been playing for four hours?" Over and over again. Either you are killing "just one more pirate" or exploring "just one more system" or mining "just one more node". It is really, really good.

Mining is fantastic as well. You have two types of mining laser mining and core mining. Laser mining is more profitable and pretty good but core mining is just *chef's kiss*. It is phenomenal. You can just play some tunes and relax while your charges blow asteroids open like cantaloupes. Seriously, it is not that complicated once you get used to it and it is fantastic.

The game is player driven and the devs have been more active in generating events. It is really fun. There are player communities with ads in game (fuel rats) that make the emerging narrative and the meta game outstanding. I wouldn't say better than Helldivers 2 but close and with far more potencial.


Now the downsides:
You need certain third party websites and tools to really play this game. The devs have improved trading somewhat and you can make a profit using the in game systems (that really could use more explanation) but third part websites make it... Easier and even simple things like calculating the profit of your possible trade based on cargo hold capacity, could and should be offered in game as well as certain elements of exo biology could do with a brushup maybe in exchange for lower rewards. It is fun to log and analyze a new type of bacteria in an alien world. It is not fun to hunt for white bacteria in a white icy planet for hours.

Again, you can have fun without these extraneous for quite a while or forever and I recommend going as blind as possible and use your in game codex. but you will reach a point where you will be at a bit of a loss. And that is something that should be fixed.

The game needs more dev based events. They are awesome and make for very good gameplay. Something like a game master like Helldivers 2 would be cool.

Walkable ship interiors. Even if you do nothing. It is such an easy win that I struggle to understand why we don't have those.

Graphics are good... But the aliasing methods are not well implemented. The amount of shimmering artifacts can be distracting especially if on foot in a settlement.

Foot combat... Is there. It exists. Serves it's purpose. But it is a far cry from the ship combat. I would love to see it improved.


Overall, I love this complex game. It scratches an itch that No Man's Sky never did for me. It is definitely worth it putting up the time and frustration.

And as an explorer who is currently over 1k light years away from the bubble, I hope I will never see any of you! But that could be the space madness talking. O7 commanders. Never fly without a rebuy.

185872852.review:
Si buscas un simulador espacial bien diseñado y medianamente interesante, este juego podria ser para ti. Sin embargo mas alla de su buena ambientacion y sus mecanicas, este juego puede facilmente llegar a sentirse monotono por el grindeo constante.

Este juego se centra principalmente en 4 actividades, luchar, minar, explorar y hacer misiones o encargos para facciones. El tema con estas actividades es que tienen poco o ningun impacto en el mundo (o galaxia) que te rodea, en cambio, se sienten como actividades repetitivas que haces solo por hacer algo, llegando a convertir la experiencia de este juego en una rutina, mas pareciendo un trabajo a que una aventura espacial. 

Recomendaria este juego solo a los fanaticos de la ciencia ficcion y la exploracion espacial, o a quienes no tengan nada mejor que hacer o jugar. Si no eres parte de ninguno de estos grupos, mejor evita este juego. A mi personalmente me gusta este juego pero no por eso se lo recomendaria a cualquiera.

Elite Dangerous es un juego que se puede resumir perfectamente con una frase, "Ancho como un oceano y profundo como un charco". Y si decides ingresar a este juego, mejor que sea con la expectativa de disfrutar la inmensidad del espacio, pero sin esperar nada mas aparte de eso.

It starts with the fact that there is no real manual. All that you need to know is out there but you need to go get it from YT (look for recent video's!), reddit, all kinds of discord channels, the excellent wiki etc.

185853955.review:
Elite Dangerous is an expansive, highly immersive space simulation game that offers players an unparalleled experience of the cosmos. Developed by Frontier Developments, this game stands out with its realistic depiction of the Milky Way galaxy, boasting over 400 billion star systems to explore. From the moment players begin their journey, they are thrust into a meticulously crafted universe where the possibilities seem endless.
One of the game's strongest points is its attention to detail. The graphics are stunning, capturing the vastness and beauty of space. Planetary landings, space stations, and star ships are intricately designed, offering a visually spectacular experience. Sound design is equally impressive, with ambient sounds and a dynamic soundtrack that enhances the immersion.
Gameplay in Elite Dangerous is diverse and complex, including trading, mining, exploration, combat, and more. The game's open-ended nature allows players to carve their own paths, fostering a sense of freedom and adventure. However, this complexity can also be a drawback for some. The learning curve is steep, and new players might find the initial stages daunting. A comprehensive tutorial and community resources help alleviate this, but it’s still a game that demands patience and dedication.
Overall, Elite Dangerous is a remarkable game that offers depth and realism in space exploration. I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys intricate simulations and has a passion for space. For those willing to invest the time to master its complexities, the rewards are profoundly satisfying, making it an adventure worth undertaking.

I want to like this game, I really do. I played the hell out of the original. And Frontier. And Frontier II. I love the idea of kitting out a deep-space explorer and just mapping distant planets, maybe do a spot of mining or exploring on the ground.

But when I've played 7 hours and I can't even complete my first goddamn milk run because the ship keeps trying to crash into a star and I have to read five Reddit threads just to figure out how to fly from one system to the next? No. It's an abusive relationship, and I'm breaking it off, Elite. Your UI is aggressively unfriendly, your in-game help is minimal, and the controls are so insanely complicated that I ran out of keybinds. There's no need for the game to be this complicated.

I know there are thousands of people who will read this and think I'm just an idiot casual, and they have hundreds of hours playing it just fine. I'm glad for them. I don't have the patience to make learning this game a second job.

185793365.review:
I played this game a few years after its release. I stopped playing it because the overall game design seemed interesting but felt monotonous. The Gameplay and combat felt dull. The progression seemed plodding for little to no overall reward or satisfaction vs the time spent in the game. In short, a lot of time spent to gain very little while the adventure being boring and uninteresting.

When i played again all these years later, i was excited to start out on an actual planet and do "things" such as fighting, stealing, hacking, researching, etc. It gave an element of fun and interest to the game that i felt was needed. However after playing for about 16 hours i felt that this was the only thing that was really added to make the overall monotonous gameplay, dull combat, and plodding progression seem worth my time. The game is still a snail paced universe of nothing. I Play a lot of grinding, exploration, and complex fantasy based games but i just could not enjoy my time in this game. I was quick to realize this game is just not for me, mostly because i value my time.

I would recommend this game if you really, really, really do not care about your personal time at all and can see your self spending hours roleplaying in a realistic space simulator as commander "x" doing "whatever" as this is a sandbox space simulator and it does good at being that.  i really enjoy these types of games and i STILL was falling asleep playing this game going from point a to b due to how travel is. There is a lot of frustration that can stem from that which is agitated from ganks of pirate npcs or players alike as well as ignorance that can lead your 10 hour irl travel time to complete waste. 

for example if you are transporting resources to make money, and you take a far distance package due to you having a large max capacity for storage, then get ganked by pirates you can lose everything. in my instance, this happened but i was able to defeat the pirate. however my things were floating nearby and i had no idea how to get them back. i figured that out and was on my way. i can't imagine the frustration of other new players who ended up on the ass end of that experience though. even with auto pilot and things, the travel is really not fun and takes a lot of setup to make it feel better from default as well as a large learning curve. If these are all things youre ok with going down the drain the second you encounter more than you can chew then go for it. but be prepared for major losses of irl time sink in ways that lead to loss of potential progression.

185729476.review:
Elite Dangerous — это настоящая жемчужина среди космических симуляторов! Впечатляющий масштаб игры, невероятно детализированный открытый мир и захватывающая механика, которая погружает в атмосферу бескрайних просторов космоса. Возможность стать частью различных фракций, заниматься торговлей, пиратством или исследовать неизведанные планеты — всё это делает игру уникальной и многогранной.

Графика потрясающая, каждый момент в игре наполняет чувство безбрежности и свободы. Управление кораблем требует навыков, но оно интуитивно понятное, что позволяет наслаждаться процессом, не отвлекаясь на лишние настройки.

Большой плюс — это постоянно обновляемый контент и сообщество игроков, с которым можно взаимодействовать в различных космических событиях. Это делает игру живой и динамичной, а каждый выбор в ней имеет значение.

"Elite Dangerous" — это настоящее космическое приключение, которое стоит того, чтобы погрузиться в него на сотни часов. Для любителей космических исследований и симуляторов — это must-play!

185704648.review:
Serious, SERIOUS grinding. The game has many missing or incomplete features. Many bugs that are present since 2019-2020. Not all of them can stop you from playing, or enjoying though. 

Despite the bugs/glitches, the game is basically a space-simulation. They made it as realistic as possible. It also has a lore with aliens and stuff. Has secrets which anyone can unfold. However, the Galaxy is huge, so the chance of unfolding those secrets is quite low. The game has different styles and mechanics. Exploration, Trading, Combat, On-foot missions, "Powerplay" (which includes the other 4). You are free to chose which gameplay you wish to play at any time. 

Now, the most important negative part of the game for me is that, you need third-party apps or websites, to enjoy the game. Without them, the game  is too shallow. Not enough information is given in-game by the developers. The most helpful/necessary one is the website called "Inara.cz". Without this website, the game would be lost in my opinion. Then there is the Elite Dangerous Market Connecter (EDMC). 

The game is time consuming really. You can't do much if you're only going to play 1-2 hours per day. You have to really commit, in order to earn money, or enjoy the mechanics. 

Besides the "cons", the game is quite fun once you get used to it. However, this game isn't new-comer-friendly. It has been 10 years or so since the launch, but the devs aren't friendly either :)

Once you get used to the game, combat is quite good. You can either play "Solo", without seeing any other players, and fighting against NPCs, or you can play in a "Private Group" with friends. You can play in Open Play. with anyone. However, it is dangerous :) Players are really good fighters, even with a small ship, they can destroy your most huge/efficient/strong ship :)

- You can also join different private groups to play with friendly strangers. 

Trading is the most boring one in my opinion. However, it is a good break from the other mechanics. You can just chill and trade stuff to earn money, or relations with different political powers/factions.

Now, Exploration, this part of the game is the most fun. It is an alone type of mechanic, however, it's really amazing. You can always find systems which haven't been discovered yet. And your name will appear on the System Map as the one discovered it. You can map planets, drop down, and scan plants and stuff. And once you return to the Bubble (where everyone is grouped), you can sell this exploration data (biological scans, planet scans, system scans). 

I can't get into Powerplay as it's too complex and detailed. There are political figures (NPCs) whom you never see, only hear about. You can pledge to them, and do missions for them. Different features (bonusses or weapons, shield) are unlocked after you level up your rank with them. This mechanic still needs a rework though (Yes, I mean the PP 2.0). 

If you have enough time, and love space and science, this is a good game. However, don't expect "fixes, major lore updates" frequently. I believe this is due to how the devs look at their own game, and the game engine they use --> It doesn't allow everything they dreamed of.

185688639.review:
Amazing idea of a game, poorly executed and no where near beginner friendly and quite frankly it's BORING. If you have a lot of time to kill you might like this game but 90% of the gameplay was traveling and 10% of it was actually getting to do something fun. Anyone that actually has to work for living will barely be able to make any progress in this game. Had to restart my first play through because I took a cargo mission got some of the cargo and didn't realize I didn't have enough cargo space. I figured hell it'll be fun to do the trips so I'll make 2. Then I saw the quest mentioned I wouldn't get credit if I didn't have the full cargo. So I abandoned the quest. The game didn't warn me that I would be charged for having the cargo in my ship and it put me in debt...with nothing else to my name...can't buy fuel or anything. Could I return the cargo and get rid of the penalty? No. Completely restarted and deleted my save. Finally got to some space combat(the whole reason I got into this game) got about 120k worth of bounties the game said I could claim. I would say the space combat was fun if it wasn't just time spent scanning a bunch of signals trying to find your target and then finally flying to your target following him like a dog chasing it's tail and holding down the pew pew button and pointing in his general direction until he went boom quite mindless. Flying and searching for the target took over twice as long as the actual combat... Spent about an hour trying to find a system using google and inara to find a station to turn in my bounties but could not for the life me turn these in. Although it was in my transactions no station would recognize them. Fine I went to another system to see if I could buy a new ship....turns out docking at another station takes your permit away for the beginner area which isn't really explained that well so I lost access to the beginner area even though I didn't accomplish much and again no warning before docking that this would happen. This station did not have a shipyard..ok finally find a station with a shipyard and make 3 more jumps. Made the trip and low and behold "docking permissions denied" with no mention of that on the star map before I made the 3 jumps to get there. And don't get me started on overshooting your targets when you're super-cruising EVERYTIME. That was my sign that the game isn't for me.

Huge time sink and absolutely nothing to show for it. Yes I tried youtube videos and tutorials but once you actually play the game it's not like what you see with the magic of video editing. If you enjoy activites such as watching paint dry or admiring grass grow then you've found the game for you. The ship flight and combat were not even interesting and that's the main reason I got the game. The immersion could be there if I didn't have to alt-tab every few minutes to one of the many tabs you need to keep open to search up things for the game. At least 5 of these play hours was just me afk googling and trying to figure out what I'm doing. The only thing dangerous about this game is the amount of type spent trying to figure out what you're doing outside of the bare bones tutorial and the only thing elite is the amount of time spent traveling between missions. Don't let my 20 hours fool you I probably got 3 hours of actual gameplay once you factor in the searching for answers outside of the game and traveling.

185641923.review:
To this day the BEST "Space Pilot in 3000 AD" simulator.  It's literally life-changing in VR- just sitting in the cockpit of a small ship... not even flying it, just SITTING in it in the hanger.  

About 40 ships you can buy, endless combinations of ship parts before you get into the RPG-side of leveling up your gear.  
Mining can be fun and relaxing.  Laser mine or maybe use bombs to blow asteroids in half.  Many options there.
Combat, either vs humans or.... others.... packs a punch and there is a lot of depth to be had there.
Trade reacts to market and plot forces.  
Finding a cool-looking thing out in space and being able to fly to it and check it out is awesome.  I've checked out constellations, black holes, nebulae, etc.  And by bringing some good research/scanning gear I've made good money doing so.
There are "community" goals where the players either work for or against certain in-game tasks that have real consequences.  Example-  One such task was to help bring supplies to make a string of space stations leading from the human-occupied "Bubble" to the center of the galaxy, "Colonia".  That sucker got done in RECORD time- the community was absolutely STARVING for a way to get to the juicy nougat center of the galaxy and as a result it was finished in record time.  There have been other times where different player groups DIDN'T want a community goal to work- and so for a week there was a constant battle over that supply line.

This game will take you an hour or three to get comfortable with how things work- but I wouldn't worry about that.  I'd mess around in super-cheap ships early on until you can takeoff/land reliably, don't even THINK about combat for a while, and just see if the whole overall flow of the game suits you.  Yeah, there is deep ship customization, combat, a faction system, the ability to custom-engineer just about everything, an entire FPS-part that I have not even started yet.... but you'll have plenty of time for all that.  I have about 1700 hours.  I'm missing 1/2 of the ships, my total worth doesn't add up to the cost of one of those Fleet Carriers..... just know there is a LOT of game here.

Oh- super-tip:  Be prepared to rebind the keys for "Fly Straight Up, Straight Down, Left, Right, Forward, Backwards, and turning your nose left and right" to keys you'd be comfortable using in a first-person shooter.... or just something along those lines.  There are a lot of times you'll want to move in any given direction but have your actual THROTTLE at ZERO, so basically if you let go of all the keys you'd come to a full stop.

I'm genuinely trying to like this game, and generally I do - but there are times when I think that I must be the Frank Spencer of intergalactic affairs!! 

There are MANY incidents which have led to this belief, but I'll limit my impending ridicule, and just mention my latest two calamitous f**k ups! :)

Firstly, on a trading mission to deliver some kind of fossil, I landed (after several aborted bouncing attempts) at some research installation on a planet's surface, in order to deliver said fossil, which I'd picked up at another far flung sh*t hole. It was here that I made the mistake of moving a couple of inches forward during a security check after thinking that my scan was all done and dusted, but................. yeah, of course it wasn't!! 

"Don't you dare!" screeched the guard, as the moaning cow, and her fellow imbeciles proceeded to introduce several holes into my character's much surprised carcass, and before I could so much as shout "Get f**ked", the screen went blank, I hit 'Continue', and awoke in a jail cell after paying a fine!  

Originally undeterred by this, despite being informed that I'd failed the mission, I left the cell, which I stupidly assumed was on the same sh*tty rock as my earlier demise, and hopped into my ship to pick up a different item from where I thought would be pretty close by. Well how f**king wrong I was!! After maybe six consecutive hyperspace jumps, I decided to re-check the galaxy map, whereupon I came to a startling realisation - that the jail cell was in fact about 10 billion light centuries away from where I'd been shot, and I only had 25% of my fuel left!  No big deal I thought, as I noticed that I was slap f**king bang in front of a 'fuel star' How hard can it be to scoop some free fuel? was what I figured as I pulled to a stop near my glowing would-be saviour, and stepped into the porch** for a quick cigarette, and a glass of water. 

** I don't mean to f**k up any kind of story immersion, but I'm talking about the porch out back of our house - I haven't managed so far at least, to build one on the side of my ship!! :D It is after all, just one of those crappy Sidewinders that ya get for free after doing the flight tutorial at the game's beginning, and was all I could afford, being devoid of any of those Arx things - and thus poorer than a church mouse, whose parents had suddenly emigrated, and taken all of the Edam with them just to rub it in further! ** 

As I came back from the porch, I heard a beeping sound, which alerted me to the discovery that my ship had almost melted, and as if that wasn't enough to p*ss on my chips, I hadn't even scooped any fuel whatsoever, because I didn't actually have a fuel scoop fitted anyway, (I thought they just came as standard, like spare wheels with new cars!) and the fuel that I did have pre-porch break had run out too! I thought just for a moment that Sh*t Creek had possibly dried up, when a new alarm notification in blue announced that my oxygen supply was about to kick me in the nads too, so I had 5 minutes to un-f**k myself, or I'd be toast! 

Suffice to say, that if it wasn't for Google, and the two angelic individuals sent from the 'Fuel Rats' website, my ship would still be there, along with the two raised middle finger bones of my commander's skeletal remains! :D 

Secondly, tonight I had landed on the surface of another barren, dusty backwater, to try and retrieve something from a crashed ship :) I had just disembarked, and was for the first time in that moon buggy thing that I forgot I had from the beginning. Not having learned anything at all from taking porch breaks, I pressed Esc to pause the game, to check on tonight's tea in the oven, which incidentally was ribs in soy sauce :D

Well the ribs were doing just fine, but my screen on the other hand, had gone dark - apart from this message:

185613314.review:
Bought Elite back in 2020, jumped in, couldn’t figure out how to fly, almost crashed, and rage-quit after 30 minutes. That was it for me… until two weeks ago. I decided to give it another shot after seeing some of the recent (Odyssey) updates, and holy crap, this game is unmatched. I feel so damn sorry for missing the Thargoid Wars and ignoring this masterpiece for four years.

I’ve tried Starfield (no thanks, Howard), X4 (too old), No Man’s Sky (fun for a while, but 60+ hours in, it just gets repetitive), and even Star Citizen (30 FPS on a 4070 S Ti for a couple of planets and a not-even-half-finished game? Yeah, no). None of these games even come close to what Elite offers.

This is a mind-blowing space sim that gives you the entire freaking Milky Way, modeled with real astronomical data. We’re talking billions of star systems, actual planet landings (yes, you can land on planets with the Odyssey update), and iconic destinations like Sagittarius A* and the Solar System. The graphics? Stunning. The ship mechanics? Deep and immersive. The lore? Rich and layered. And don’t even get me started on the dogfights—space combat in this game is on a whole other level.

There’s something for everyone: different missions at every station and hub, different playstyles for exploration, bounty hunting, mining, trading and more. Into galactic politics? Powerplay adds lore-driven action gameplay. Want to land on a planet, hop in your planetary vehicle, and roam around? You got that too. Prefer managing your ship’s power in the heat of a dogfight to outmaneuver your enemies? Yep, it’s all there. Feel like grabbing a gun and fighting on foot? Absolutely. and it's an MMO.

I could go on and on about everything you can do, but honestly, the best part is discovering it yourself.

If you’re just starting out and using a keyboard and mouse, trust me on this: swap roll and yaw controls. Put roll on the keyboard (A and D) and yaw on the mouse—it makes flying so much easier. If you’re unsure how to do it, Google it, or add me and I’ll help you. Also, do yourself another favor and search ‘what is Elite rebuy?’—it will save you and your ship :)

And also don’t forget to check out the EliteDangerous subreddit—seriously, the community there is super welcoming and helpful with literally anything you need.

Honestly, if space sims had their own 'souls-like' category, the standard would be called elite-like. Remember, this game is tough to learn and takes time, but absolutely worth it.

185578362.review:
As a bit of a Space nerd, this game ticks all the boxes. Realistic Space travel (including travel times) around a version of OUR Galaxy set about a thousand years in the future. If you're familiar with No Man's Sky, you'll understand the basic concept of the game, but how it's carried our is far more realistic/technical/in depth. Because of this, there is a real difficulty curve, learning to control your ship is a pain in the ass, if you don't watch the tutorials.  
The nerves of flying into a space station unaided for the first time, and the satisfaction looking over the rings of a Gas Giant while you're docked on a player owned Freighter, there's not much that beats it for me. 
Definitely helps that it's actually gorgeous, the closest thing to photo realistic Space travel that I've played. (Sorry Star Citizen, I'm not there yet)
I will say, it does feel a little aimless as there is no 'main quest' in this game so it's more about making your own way in the black. Earning a name for your self through Trade, Combat and Exploration, primarily. There is an ongoing story and it is affected by players, but it's more a community thing, where every player's activities contribute to a 'Background Simulation'. 
There are things to unlock, Medals to earn but finding them may prove a little tricky without outside help. 
On that note I find my time in game is heavily dependant on External websites like inara.cz, while incredibly useful, they're almost too good, as they show far more detail about the galaxy than you can generally find in game.
I absolutely love this game, my Steam record says 695 Hours, that's in the last 2 months. And that doesn't include the 44 days on Xbox, probably over the last 8 years or so.
I will always recommend it, but there are, unfortunately, always a lot of caveats.

185561472.review:
A unique and ambitious space simulation game.  

The combat and flight mechanics are excellent, with a clever mix of simulation and arcade elements that make the experience incredibly satisfying. For me, it’s the best in its class, even today.  

The space environments are stunning, and the sound design is some of the most impressive I’ve ever heard in a game.  

However, the main issue with this so-called exploration game is... the exploration itself. The developers haven’t pushed this aspect far enough. Points of interest and random events all feel very similar. Even with the *Odyssey* expansion, exploration is often reduced to scanning the same three types of plants on every planet.  

Lately, the developers seem to be focusing more on improving political simulations between factions rather than enhancing the exploration experience—which is rather ironic for a game that claims to center on space discovery.  

If you want to play Risk or Politico in 3D, this game is for you. If you’re looking for true space science exploration, you’d be better off reading a book.

185505807.review:
Редко пишу обзоры, но этот случай заслуживает внимания. Я долго ждал эту игру, изучал её через стримы и видео, и, к сожалению, сильно разочаровался после покупки.

Пунктов можно перечислять очень много, скорее всего какие-то я позабуду упомянуть.
Реализм:
1.Физика и реализм- По умолчанию включен автопилот и физика с ним далека от реальности, скорее напоминает условный авиасимулятор. Конструктивно корабли не практичные. Чувство что вы летаете не на космическом корабле, а на космоплане.

Орбитальное торможение и ускорение в игре упрощены до гравитационных полей и ям, без учёта вращения тел, например. Гравитация — единственный фактор, влияющий на корабль. (в KSP это сделано куда лучше, как по мне)

Многие объекты в игре нельзя пролететь насквозь, так как они сделаны как статичные модели, а не динамические структуры, и сверхсветовой двигатель (FSD) блокирует приближение. Посадки на планеты требуют планирования, но реализация ограничена и учитывает только угол входа, который сложно определить без опыта.

Интерфейс:

Главное меню и настройки игры выглядят стильно, но на этом плюсы заканчиваются. 
В игре представлены четыре панели с несколькими режимами просмотра и подменю, однако обучение необязательное и поверхностное, из-за чего первые часы придется интуитивно разбираться, а про некоторые вещи вообще не факт что догадаешься пока кто-то не скажет. Управление неудобное: стандартные настройки охватывают не все функции, требуя ручной настройки, а доступ к важным меню слишком медленный для динамичных условий игры. (как выбор конкретного модуля цели)

Если вы хотите просмотреть данные или проложить маршрут, всё работает нормально. Однако, для наведения на конкретный модуль цели нужно отвлечься от обзорного окна, нажать несколько клавиш, и в длинном списке выбрать нужный модуль. Это занимает около 5-10 секунд, за которые вы можете получить 1-3 атаки, наносящие значительный урон щитам или корпусу или биндить клавишу промотки этого списка, который всё ещё может быть долгим.

Некоторые оповещения, мне кажется, можно было сделать заметнее. 
Навигация по меню сложна. Меню могли бы быть гораздо лучше, с выводом важной информации на обзорное окно, которое ничем особо не занято. Закрепить тоже ничего нельзя. Подсказки клавиш отсутствуют.

Настройка огневых групп ограничена двумя клавишами (ПКМ и ЛКМ), хотя для полноценного управления требуется около пяти и более клавиш. Управление в меню непоследовательное: где-то используется Enter, где-то пробел, а где-то курсор может не работать.

Бой - нормальный, больше сказать нечего.

Оружие - В игре большинство типов оружия неудобны и неэффективны, и игроки часто используют лишь несколько видов, таких как пучковые лазеры, многоствольные орудия и рельсотроны/плазменые ускорители (которые намного лучше всего остального). Оружие другого типа применяется редко и в основном в PVE-режиме. 

Также важным аспектом является улучшение оружия через инженеров, что делает прогресс в игре сложным и обязательным для развития. (даже если вы не хотите заниматься добыванием ресурсов, придётся)

Также есть некоторые другие полезные фракционные модули которые требуется гриндить достаточно долгое время. (зависит от фракции и многих других вещей)

Инженеры не открыты сразу, и не обо всех из них вы вообще знаете. Надо работать с одними чтобы узнать о других. (как говорит вики)

PVP - В игре большая, но пустая галактика, где шанс встретить других игроков, особенно вдали от начального сектора, очень низкий. Мне за время моей игры в открытой игре посчастливилось встретить не более 20 человек. (в достаточно населённых районах). Если у вас нет друзей или группы, скорее всего, вам предстоит играть в одиночку. Однако есть арена для встреч с игроками и "Топливные крысы", которые помогут с топливом и советами.

PVE - Игра предлагает много интересных занятий, таких как инопланетяне, пиратство, исследование, торговля и миссии, но они слишком типичны и однообразны. Игра требует универсальности, но не предоставляет четкого сюжета или обязательных миссий. Заработок в игре скучен, а на вид динамичные бои, слишком типичны и быстро надоедают. 

Процесс посадки на планеты и станции слишком усложнён, что превращает игру в скучный симулятор с долгими ожиданиями, которые могли бы быть автоматизированы или сделаны опциональными для игрока.

При этом, не у всех кораблей средних и больших размеров по умолчанию есть автопилот. посадочные системы, что говорит о том, что вам придётся жертвовать местом под модуль или делать это вручную, и большая часть ваших таких посадок приведёт к получению штрафа, отзыву разрешения на посадку, уничтожению вашего корабля, и повторного полёта через несколько систем (иногда больше десятка) на вашем корабле (иногда вообще не приспособленном для таких полётов) до нужной вам системы обратно, из местной тюрьмы. Не понимаю почему было не сделать системы для автопилота отдельными повсеместными модулями.

Корабли - В игре много кораблей, но лишь несколько из них действительно полезны. Большинство других кораблей — это неэффективные и бесполезные модели в сравнении. В игре есть лишь несколько достойных универсалов. Лишь одна линейка грузовых, транспортных и 4 линейки фракционных кораблей (одну я бы назвал условной). Колличество полезных кораблей сводиться к единицам. При этом вы можете пропустить некоторые виды кораблей, нафармив побольше.

Основными плюсами этой игры я могу назвать графику, открытый мир, и топливных крыс (ребята, вы лучшие). Ещё мне понравились наземные конфликты если вы играете с друзьями (можно побегать и пострелять, но быстро надоест). Можно поиграть вместе.

Всё остальное это один большой жирный минус. В игру просто скучно играть (особенно в соло), так игра ещё и заставляет страдать вас в мелких моментах буквально в каждой возможности. Всё развитие сводиться к тому что вы фармите новые кораблики и новые ранги, при этом гемплей не меняется сильно. Это всё те же кораблики, с тем же управлением, почти с той же кабиной, с теми же цветами, с теми же заданиями, но немного разной компоновкой и возможностями.

В обзоре не упомянуты некоторые другие раздражающие моменты, которые описывать будет слишком долго и которые скорее зависят от моих представлений от гемплея.

Также игра без DLC лишает вас некоторых ключевых функций и поверхностных миссий, поэтому без него игра была бы ещё хуже. Но поскольку я пока не встретил не одной наземной динамичной миссии (наподобие той которую вы видите в обучении когда первый раз попадаете в игру), я не уверен что оно должно столько стоить. Как я понимаю оно даёт лишь инженеров которые жизненно необходимы для апдейтов корабля и может что-то ещё.

Донат чисто косметический и валюта легко копиться сама пока вы играете и выполняете миссии, поэтому тут ничего страшного.

Также учитывайте что всё об игре вам придётся учить через википедию или что-то ещё кроме самой игры. В игре это сделано достаточно плохо и не даёт полной детальной картины.

Музыка в игре хорошая. Некоторые композиции слушал даже до самой игры. Хотя для меня класическая музыка при посадке это немного не то. Ну и переоформить её как-то тоже нельзя. В боях какой-то динамичной тоже не заметил.

Как по мне, игра по полной своей стоимости совсем того не стоит. По скидке, возможно, но только если по РЕАЛЬНО большой.

How shall I describe this game? Lets start somewhere simple, what does the game feel like? To me, it felt like space trucker sim. But that's not all there is to this game, its also at times an idle game in a way, due to waiting for a time to travel from one place to another. I have heard that the game has a pvp scene, never touched it, would rather play "singleplayer" as it can be called and face the ai.

The first time I got interdicted outside the tutorial, I was not ready, Being put into a combat situation was jarring, hard, and overwhelming in some ways, that said, I was not piloting a ship made for combat, and the game has that as a potential.

Combat, can be a fast paced thing, with the right ship and the right custom equipment on the ship, you can face down anything you want within reason and within your own skill level, because skill is not optional for fights, its a must.

All that said, I played this game as a mining ship, I played this game as a goods transport ship, I played this game as a space bus-man, and I have had friends who enjoyed the combat. This is a good game, if you have the patience. If your attention span is not enough to last through this comment, this may not be the game for you, but give it a go anyways! See if it is your cup of tea.

Oh, Little side note at the end of this, I played this game and all 115 hours (as of the time of this review) On an absolute potato of a computer with shit ram and a shitty graphics card. Take the minimum requirements with a grain of salt, you might be able to play them with something as good as a desktop made for windows xp running modern windows with only 6 gigs of ram (two gigs of it not the same brand) and an old amd graphics card from 2011 with 4 gigs of vram and a single core intel processor running a whopping 2.1ghz speed (wow, so awesome) So if your computer is better than that, even slightly, give this a go (especially if you see it on sale)

There's only human NPC's could be effective to add different races, lifeforms, and colonies. I know this sounds life X4 or Spacebourne 2 but the game feels really bland and old school and needs to catch up on what players really want! Not only that you'll beat Star Citizen at there own game.

Just 1 step at a time!

185486961.review:
I've always wanted to give this game a try since its release but I never had the setup to play it, I only got it recently for a pretty big discount and I gotta say this game really makes my jaw drop every time I learn something new.

My experience as a new player learning the curves is definitely something that needed patience, interest, and curiosity. At first I thought just learning how to do the on-foot, flight, and mining tutorial would be the end of it but afterwards you see all these menu that you really don't know how to navigate through. Fortunately, I have played a lot of RPG games so I was prepared for this. Then you don't really know where to start, like what to do first? I click this and that until I figure out how to accept missions, oh I also didn't know where to go in the station, there was no arrows, no objective markers, just straight up following the signs on the stations.

To get myself to know the basics, it didn't really require me to do any research at all, it was really just me curiously using the terminal to access the mission board, talking to the guy in Inter Astra to unlock my Sidewinder, and do some missions. Now this is where things became a whole more interesting, I was definitely eager to go on combat and shoot stuff up but I felt that could ruin my enjoyment and the learning process, could've made me give up on trying the game and just refund it but I was reasonable, realistically if you were a new guy being tasked with the freedom of choosing jobs then obviously I picked the safest route which was transporting and delivery. It was mundane for sure, you just go from point A to point B but for some reason I felt immersed and relaxed just scouring through space and landing on planets it felt like therapy for me after playing intensive games that are just fast-paced of kill or be killed. The payment I got for doing those jobs were also rewarding, like getting your first pay in your first job and at the time I also thought the money was plenty.

So I started exploring the catalog of existing ships and that's when I started researching through online means, how do you get these ships? Why are some of them grayed out even though I have the money? Why this, why that. Then I found it, the website that provides a tool for us to use, you can use it to find the ships you want, the components you want, just through a couple of clicks, tells you which system is the closest from you to get those items. The website I'm referring to was INARA, it was almost like a bible that you need to pocket at all times because you're not getting anywhere without it.

Then I set my goal for this game, it was to be a Mercenary after researching on what kind of careers you can pick up in this game. Though of course, being a merc with a starter ship like Sidewinder would be like jumping into a Rank S Quest with just a knife in your hand so I set my sights on the Krait Mk II, it fit with my taste of aesthetics and I heard it was one of the best ships you can get. So I continued my job as a delivery man. Also I'd like to add it was also confusing because when I was doing deliveries, I had to roam around where to give and where to get the objectives of my delivery though again in the end with some curiosity I was able to figure it out thanks to the terminals.

Ok so I did back and forth doing some deliveries, then I thought is there a better or a more efficient way to make fortune? Because this can take months. That's when I started to get deeper on my research, finding videos and guides. I found out that being an Exobiologist could earn you a lot of money so I tried it out, it was confusing at first with all the scanning the planet thing and the outfitting of the ship you gotta have so you can go as far as possible from the starting system, but with some patience I was able to figure it out and landed on a planet that was almost devoid of life but my scanners said there might some life here so I searched. Found my first scan, drove a couple hundred meters with my SRV, found another one, scan, until I found the 3rd one that was when it was complete.

After that, I went back to a station that has something called the Vista Genomics using INARA as my guide. I was able to sell all my scanned stuff and holy it made my jaw drop, the potential money I can make through this so I thought I can probably get my Krait Mk II soon. So I continued as an exobiologist.

40 hours later and here we are, Krait Mk II. This wouldn't have happened if I was playing games like War Thunder. The ship was beautiful, I thought it was an impossible dream but then I looked up online again. This was not a good course to take, why? Because I was limited in experience and knowledge and rushing it like this could end up badly, but this time I was bold so I tried to find Threat 0 Combat Missions. I flew the ship and found my target, went to combat and it was very satisfying getting my first ship kill (unlike previously when I went to Conflict Zones to gather money for my exobiologist expedition to upgrade my Hauler where I sort of steal kills from friendly NPCs and reap the reward) even though the money reward was on the smaller side but I knew this was it, soon I can be a proper Merc.

So now I'm still learning, there's builds I want to get for my Krait Mk II to make it even more formidable in combat but I will need money, materials, and other things so I'll just enjoy my time in Elite Dangerous.

Ok I ended up telling my playthrough for this review, in the end I think if you're looking for something "realism and immersion" in an affordable space sim this could be a game for you. I played No Man's Sky before, even though I think the game is well made it didn't click with me maybe it didn't fit my taste of aesthetics and as for games like Star Citizen I just think Elite Dangerous is more friendly towards your hardware and money. Though there are micro-transactions in this game, I was surprised that you can get the premium currency just by doing activities and could earn you up to 400 (cap) per week, not many games does that and the pricing of the premium currency well I thought it was still on the more affordable side than most premium battle passes this days but again if it can be cheaper then the better so I hope FD won't become greedy and improve upon this or at least just stay on course for people like me who's a bit on the more limited side of budget.

Overall I think this game does cater to specific people, some people who's more fast-paced driven shouldn't get this game. I don't think the game is very time consuming that you have to play like a no-lifer, manage your time well and you can still complete a lot of things here. Again I cannot stress this enough but it does require you to have patience, interest, and curiosity in order to enjoy this game and maybe a little bit of appreciation to enjoy the vast empty space yet beautiful view.

Thanks for reading my review.

185385198.review:
So... Elite Dangerous. If you buy this game, you will get the chance to fly a space craft that can allow to explore a One-to-One representation of our beautiful home galaxy, The Milky Way Galaxy. You will be able to view the absolute beauty of our galaxy, in game. Not only will you be able to explore, but also get into "space combat" as a pirate, bounty hunter, or take sides in power play and fight in hot zones where you go against capital class ships. You can also be a space trucker and transport goods across the many stars of the galaxy. And you can also be a space miner and collect space rocks to sell. And if you have VR, the game becomes one of the best VR game available.

Here is the problem with the game. The vastness of space in this game is very empty. There is absolutely no story telling like a Bethesda game where you have an NPC tell you that the solar system that you are in is a complete dump or filled with rich traders. This very much a player goal oriented game and not a story game which this game would excel at if the devs pushed a story. Ok so the game has player goals right? Yes it does. it consist of you grinding for credits to buy new ships and obtaining engineering materials to upgrade those ships which could take hours of you booting the game on and off to obtain the materials. Never in the history of gaming have I ever had to turn my game On and then OFF to grind for materials for upgrades. It's an absolute joke in terms of game design. Another problem with the game to enhance the grind experience is having the need to install or use third party sources to obtain information needed to make the experience of grinding easier. Players of this game have been begging the devs to implement these third party software/websites into the game to help players advance their space journey but the devs are adamant to not bring these tools into the game. The game also lacks ship interiors. You will only be stuck in the cock pit and will be unable to walk around and explore your ship that you paid credits for. Something that this games competitor (Star Citizen) offers generously. 

With all that said. The game is still worth playing simply for what the game actually is. A One-to-One space exploration game of our own galaxy. There is no other games like this outside of star citizen. The sound effects of this game is absolutely flawless. Space combat is fun and an absolute dream in VR. Parking your ship in a star port manually for the first time is probably one of the best feelings ever! The good in this game out ways the bad. My personal rating for this game is 7/10 tacos. 8/10 tacos if played in VR. And it also gets a 9/10 tacos if you play it in VR and have some form of a joystick and throttle for the full experience.

Elite Dangerous is the a space sim that has quite deep learning curve with it. Do the tutorials and get the hang of it first, and you will be fine. There are lots of different things to do in the game, and also very active player groups if you need help to start or want to play in teams. 

And despite the many video tutorials, there is no need to achieve billions in few hours to buy everything. Play with slower pace and learn while playing.

"Blaze your own trail in the galaxy".  Remember, this is a sand box game, and you need to set your own goals over and over again. They can be small like "Now I collect enough materials to upgrade my favorite guns to level 5", or bigger "Now I trade enough to buy me Type-9 Heavy".  You set the goals, enjoy the ride.

This game is a bit like The Sims 4, you always hope that the gameplay somehow will get better than it is so you keep exploring things, buying DLC and trying new ships but it never really loses that "it's more work than play" feeling. You will be doing the same thing over and over again to get money, and in the back of your mind, you will always wish you were doing something more fun....

That being said, it's still a good time in small bursts and the new ships are very well made which does inject some excitement into the mix. Unfortunately I am not a big fan of doing all manner of weird tasks to get materials to engineer these ships to max levels and wish it was more transparent on what you have to do, or having every mat farmable from every playstyle instead of the wide range of tasks needed. Also please FDev, having to log in and out to farm something is kinda terrible, hope that gets addressed.

So why do I recommend this then? It's still one of the best direct control space sims out there and is getting more and more fleshed out. Everything from on foot to Fleet Carrier scale is here and, while bare bones, still can be interesting and immersive. I have a feeling that in a few years it might even be fun for longer, but that's just a wish. What is here though is still something I delve into from time to time, especially with a long stream on the side to help mitigate the monotony. If you're into that then go ahead, but if not stay away and check back later.

Recently I have been fiddling around in Elite Dangerous and have had loads of fun not only in pancake mode but VR mode as well. If you are a space nut like me and realize that we will not be alive to know how it is to traverse space and scam people for gold on the market and that makes it more of an incentive to play. It does everything right but also does the wrong things even wrongererer. This Game is not your friend and will not hold your hand outside of the tutorials and this goes for everything in the game. Along with that some things are more tedious then they need to be even though it is a sim. But dont let it throw you off, this is a 1:1 scale of the universe and you are but the smallest speck making a difference and you feel that, even in the most dense of systems you still feel lonely and small. This shows its true colors when doing missions, every mission is different depending on the station, and you have a wide variety of the types of missions you can take which is a nice little cherry on top giving you the opportunity to shape who you want to be in the galaxy. I could go on and on about this game but Id say give it a swing if you like to dedicate your time to something  that requires you to shape what kind of game it is. so sit back and enjoy a game company that knows there stuff when it comes to space.

7/10 - I have ED

185230921.review:
This is game is like a journey, a unique experience. A literal space sim. You feel immersed at every second of this game. You are flying a space ship through galaxies, unknown regions, uncharted systems. You are coming face to face with stars, landing on planets. You are free to do whatever you like, there is no limitations. There are lots of things to do, and lots of things to explore. Take your pick from combat, trading, exploration and many more. This is truly liberating. I have not seen any other immersive experience like this. It all feels real, like you are the one sitting in that cockpit. 
This game will get you feeling different from others. Don't be overwhelmed, there is too much to learn but for a start training only takes half an hour at most. And that is more than enough for you to enjoy it. Then if you would like you can always learn and look up more. There are so many things to learn and to do. Just start small and keep adding to it as you enjoy the game. Don't stress yourself, let the experience guide you.

185183770.review:
Elite Dangerous is a work of art. There are so many complex systems that were put together in a beautiful fashion and I believe the developers either accomplished or nearly accomplished all that they set out to do. 

First and foremost, Elite Dangerous is not a game. It is a futuristic space exploration simulator that is attempting to replicate as much realism, physics and science as the engine can support. After around 15+ hours invested I realized I was enjoying this much more than I've enjoyed my usual rotation of games.

UPDATE: I originally submitted a negative review of this game, and then I tried to edit it and Steam threw my edits out. Instead of redoing all that work I'm going to summarize a few points that new players need to bear in mind.

THIS SIM WILL NOT HOLD YOUR HAND.  If you hate learning by making mistakes, you're going to be very, very frustrated.

If you do not have a flight controller, look for tutorials on how to better map the keyboard and mouse controls before you start doing flight missions. Trust me on this one, the defaults are terrible.

This sim is very, very simmy. Most players will probably want to do as many tutorial missions as possible before starting actual missions in the main game. I was not so patient, therefore I've been learning "the hard way".

The initial flight training that is required before you can fly your ship puts you on training wheels. An actual mission will feel very different. That's normal.

Get very comfortable with looking things up online.

If you don't like Star Trek, NASA, Space X or sci fi in general, you probably will not enjoy Elite Dangerous. If you do like these things, I highly recommend giving it a try, especially if its on sale.

As an apology to Frontier for my initial negative review, I'll be picking up some ARX even though I normally don't spend real money on in-game currency.

185098303.review:
came here looking for some gold, found diamonds instead. i genuinely feel so bad for missing out on this for over 10 years. (a little heads up before you read: i don't claim to be experienced and i definitely am not experienced. this review is from a beginner's perspective.)

this game has the steepest learning curve i've ever seen in my life but it is pretty rewarding after you get the hang of how things work. this could be discouraging for some but if you like space, exploration, or anything related, i recommend the game regardless. yes, the only criterion for me to recommend this game is whether you like space or not.

tutorials on youtube and the game's wiki will be your best friends in learning how to play. if you dont like that idea, you can always join some beginner friendly squadrons in the game and ask any question to experienced players.

sure, some people may not like the excessive grind on some aspects or find the game "pointless" as it doesn't have any end goal and that it's just about buying new ships and what not. i get them, reviews are meant to be totally subjective anyway. i do think however that people who say the game is "pointless" would also enjoy the game if they lived the moment and didn't worry about what they will have ahead of them after completing their current objective. the journey itself you embark on is pretty fascinating with the amount of detail the game offers. based on this, im pretty sure you will not run out of things to do for a fairly good amount of time, also considering how active the community is on various other platforms. i personally enjoyed this game a lot in my very limited amount of playtime, knowing damn well that there's no end goal. im also willing to play a lot more.

if you are interested, there are countless systems waiting to be discovered, countless goods to be hauled, countless asteroids to be mined, countless conflicts involving combat to be a part of, countless rare goods to be smuggled, countless life forms to be logged, and practically infinite amount of bounties to be claimed in the milky way. hope to see you in the game. o7

185056789.review:
Literally nub player here. I bought the game on Christmas sale for ~8 euros, dlc included, so I was set back with 2 beers (not the end of the world). I thought what the hell, it can't be worse than Loadfield. All I wanted was a shooter, in space if possible, maybe with some cool ships and a bit of real exploration. I launched it and did the on-foot tutorial (not knowing I'm doing the on-foot tutorial) and although it looked interesting I felt like I was somewhere in HL2 in terms of graphics. After finishing the tutorial and being dumped in the starter space city I managed to exit the game and optimize the graphic settings. Restarted and deliberately done the full space flight tutorial from the tutorials menu. Man, I can't say it was that hard but damn, it felt so uncomfortable. No joystick, no nothing. Just keyboard and mouse. The game looked absolutely better after putting the correct graphic settings for my rig but damn the space controls felt... almost uncontrollable. Managed not to crash my ship, managed to finish the tutorial, NOT managed how to shoot the minigun even though I was able to understand the secondary weapon is bound to mouse2. Killed everything with weapon no.1 aka the laser beam. Did more tutorials because I felt like John Snow, I knew NOTHING. Stood like a moron for minutes in the basic flight when asked to tilt my ship with the mouse until I realized I was in free look mode aka mouse3. Did the mining tutorial, realizing that if I have to scoop every time I mine something I may loose my freaking mind. Did the manual landing tutorial and did it well, even though it took longer than expected. Decided I will always use the auto land/launch from now on. All in all, tutorials left me more confused than I'd expect so I decided to go all in and see what the actual game has to offer. To my surprise before I could leave the starting city I had to do the full space flight tutorial all over again, because this time a NPC asked me to do it before I could access the ship dock elevator. This time around I managed to shoot the minigun, who would've thought it had a spin-up time and I had to keep mouse2 down before it actually started shooting. But while fighting the drones I kinda forgot the ship moves better when also pressing A & D, so this time around it took me even longer to maneuver and turn the ship around. Frustration grew, but looking back at it, that was definitely my fault. In the end I managed to actually fly my ship for the first time for real, then land back to the starting city. Then wasted a ton of time trying to figure out how to access my inventory. For REAL! I had to GOOGLE how to OPEN MY INVENTORY, even after going though all the keybinds. That was the last straw. If I have to google a simple freaking task as opening my backpack - that means everything else will be much more frustrating. I have almost 2000 hours in No Man's Sky, don't even get me started about EVE(ry phycho) Online, but this game is a different beast. I'm not saying it's a bad game, because I literally know 0.01% of what it has to offer, but the learning curve for a beginner is very discouraging. It was easy to find the shop though.
So, if you're new and excited, all I can say is take your time. I may not abandon it but after the tutorials I'm at a bit of a loss. Not sure if it's worth the time investment in learning it via google. That's why I can't give it a thumbs up for now, sorry.

185042686.review:
Ich schreib an sich selten negative Rezensionen, aber bei diesem Game war die Enttäuschung einfach zu groß. An sich nach außen hin ein echt cooles Spiel, aber halt leider für Anfänger komplett besch*ssen reinzufinden. Es wird einem nichts erklärt, bis auf die 20 einzelnen Tutorials die man extern vom Gameplay für die grobe Steuerung machen kann, nur um dann in einer Mission festzustellen, dass man nichtmal genau weiß wie man wo hinkommt. Und dann sind die Missionen auch noch zeitlich begrenzt, mit der REALEN Zeit. Schön am Abend eine Mission starten und am nächsten Tag nach Feierabend weitermachen ist nicht. Damit schön die Fraktion, für die man die Mission macht, einen noch weiter hasst, nur weil man vom Spiel aus selbst nichts gesagt bekommt. Ich hatte echt Lust auf das Spiel, aber wenn man, um überhaupt reinzufinden, sich 300 Tutorial Videos anschauen und 40 Third-Party-Seiten nutzen muss, vergeht einem schnell die Lust. 
Und ich bin noch nichtmal bei der schrecklichen Schiffsteuerung angekommen. Ich hab einige Stunden in No Mans Sky und wer das Spiel bereits gespielt hat, weiß, dass die Steuerung im Weltraum anfangs gewöhnungsbefürftig ist. Aber die Steuerung von Elite Dangerous gibt einem, wenn man nicht schon genug vom Spiel selbst verwirrt ist, den Rest.

Ich kann mir vorstellen, dass es einem Spaß macht, wenn man bereits 100 Stunden in dem Spiel hat und bereits mehr weiß, oder wenn man sich die Ausbildung zum Elite-Dangerous-Spieler durch Anschauen von 1000 Tutorials antun will, um später mal sein Geld mit dem Spiel verdienen zu können. (So fühlt sich das nämlich an)

Ich kann das Spiel leider nicht mehr zurückgeben, weil ich zu viel Zeit in den Tutorials verbracht habe. Und das ohne eine Mission abgeschlossen zu haben. Aber wüsste eh nicht wie das geht.

Elite Dangerous gave me [b]incredible memories.[/b] My first hyperspace jump? [i]Awe-inspiring.[/i] My first accidental boost into a space station? [list]

Terrible controls, the interface is the opposite of user friendly and so is the gameplay.

The starter suit doesn't have a slot for a primary weapon, of course the game won't tell you this, you have to waste your time to first fail in combat, then google how to solve the problem.
The combat itself feels incredibly rusted (both on land and in space), I've seen better flight responsiveness in mobile games. The ground enemies are bullet sponges with AI so terrible it might compete with that of Redfall.

The controls on everything are downright terrible;
The ship is controlled by the mouse, both the roll and yaw are within a few degrees of mouse rotation, this means you will spin constanty until you rebind the controls to somthing reasonable for human use.
The cars control scheme is so scuffed that the keys for throttle (Forgot to mention that both the spaceships and cars don't stop moving then you release the throttle keys, yes it is as comfortable as you think)  are 'Q' and 'E", who the hell uses those for controlling the speed of the vehicle!?
The hotkeys for the suit are just as bad, the interface has zero hints as to how you're supposed to access any of your items. At least the movement is set to WASD, these devs could very well create a character control set never seen before in the history of gaming...

I don't understand who would want this convoluted mess of a game, in the entire 5 hours I've played it I've felt nothing but confusion and frustration at how terrible the entire experience was.
I imagine people who play this are just in it for the "immersion" of a space sim and don't actually care about any of the qualities one would expect from a game as a form of interactive media, as well as therever this could be considered a good one with how it lacks many of those qualities.. 
Well, it's their time and money, I won't argue with how they choose to spend them.

Thank you Frontier Developers, I regret buying the deluxe edition of the game, as well as, wasting almost 5 hours of my life on it.

Flying spaceships never felt so good. The trouble is, this game does not respect your time and other players are a problem.
You can spend weeks and weeks building up bounties or getting discovery data only to lose it in a single second, usually by having it taken from you by another player. Engaging in the meta game only works if you are willing to spend 4-5 hours a day just doing missions and getting bounties in combat zones. The grind is real.
Losing your ship costs far too much money; so much that it can take you hours and hours to build back up the money to be able to risk flying the same ship again. Playing in open (with other players) is a substantial risk as most players are out to get you and will kill you if you see you. Frontier Developments have never meaningfully addressed the rampant player ganking that goes on and after 9 years, I don't think they will.
Forth buying in a sale, and worth playing for some of the stunning visuals, but it soon becomes frustrating for new players at how slowly the grind is.

184897987.review:
3 friends bought the game to try it out and see if we could Multiplayer.  We found no Mans Sky to be a bit simple and without much purpose, but we all uninstalled Elite Dangerous after 3-4 hours.  Ungainly controls, pretty ordinary graphics and it was certainly not easy to play with friends.   There was no information about the difference between the standard game and the premium pack either (it included DLC Odyssey) and that meant that one of us started in a completely different area from the other two (who couldn't work out how to find each other anyway).
If you are looking for something straightforward to play with mates, this is not it.  If you are nuts about space games and are will to research and youtube in order to get you through something that doesn't hold your hand, then it'd probably end up being an ok game.

184878378.review:
Elite Dangerous es un juego increíble y altamente inmersivo, que destaca por su realismo. Se adapta a todo tipo de jugadores, ya que ofrece una amplia variedad de actividades: puedes unirte a una facción y participar en combates, completar misiones de sigilo o pirateo, o elegir opciones más tranquilas como el transporte de mercancías y paquetes. También cuenta con un robusto sistema de comercio y, para los amantes de la exploración, la posibilidad de descubrir y mapear nuevos planetas, aterrizar en ellos y buscar formas de vida únicas. Encontrar un planeta inexplorado o dar la primera pisada es una experiencia muy gratificante, ya que tu nombre quedará registrado y visible para el resto de la comunidad.

Eso sí, el juego puede sentirse algo lento al principio, y tiene una curva de aprendizaje pronunciada mientras te familiarizas con los controles. No es raro estrellar la nave unas cuantas veces al inicio, pero con un copiloto como ChatGPT, esta experiencia se vuelve mucho más accesible. Puedes pedirle recomendaciones sobre qué hacer, qué nave comprar, qué módulos instalar o resolver cualquier duda que te surja, eliminando así la necesidad de recurrir constantemente a tutoriales.

Si eres un jugador paciente, apasionado por la temática espacial y los simuladores realistas, te gustará.

Pd: El juego sí incluye voces en español.

When a game does tutorials, normally those give you all the information you need to play the game. This one does not. The tutorials are skippable which is great, but playing the necessary tutorials does not give you all the information to play. You'd think it would tell you how to do basic things like fueling, or outfitting your ship.  And when you try to find more information, there is no contextual way to find out/they don't make sense. The UI is so unintuitive my hands physically hurt after trying to play this game. 

My favorite part is how the flight tutorial instructs you on how to do stuff that the starter ship doesn't even have the capabilities of, even though it's the same model.

And, between the signing up for yet another account, and the length of the tutorials, you'll pass the two hour mark and can't even get a refund.

In Star Citizen, I fly close enough with really fast in system thrusters and get a waypoint to fly to after talking to landing services. In Elite, I try to fly close enough to my target, but pass it over by 7 days in the span of 2 seconds trying to slow down the FSD that is still engaged for some reason even though other times its not engaged still after a jump. Since I missed it, I had to try to fly sublight to it and even with boosts it's a solid 5 day flight. I could try to FSD jump to it, but it's light seconds away not light years. Overall just not a user friendly experience. I would recommend Star Citizen in it's unfinished state over this game. Disappointed

184785028.review:
Elite Dangerous is THE spaceship piloting simulation. If you love the idea of flying through the cold void of space in a tin can, one malfunction away from destruction... If high-speed dogfights around colossal space stations and smuggling illicit goods sounds like your idea of a good time... and you want it all simulated to such an exacting degree that just successfully landing your ship is a challenge, and by the time you know how, you'll feel like you know enough about spaceship piloting to do it in real life? Then you'll absolutely adore this game.

There's a whole galaxy of stars and planets (the Milky Way, rendered in full) just waiting to be jumped to, fuel-scooped, surveyed, landed on, and explored- and even now, new discoveries are still being made. There's alien life to find, sample, catalogue, interact with, and run away from (or shoot, if that's your thing.) and a myriad of stations and human characters to meet, talk to, and trade with as well. (or shoot, if that's your thing.) And if none of that appeals to you, well... a special reward awaits players who can make the long journey to Hutton Orbital. ;)

184783227.review:
I don't even know where to start.

Let’s begin with the basics:
The tutorial is completely overwhelming, especially for someone new to space simulation games (yes, this is my first one). I had to open the controls overview in a browser on my second monitor just to keep track of how to play the game. The sheer number of possibilities to control every aspect of your ship is incredible, but for a newbie like me, it’s utterly overwhelming and confusing.

I spent nearly two hours just trying to get to my first mission. In the end, I gave up because it was so frustrating to constantly look up controls on a second screen—I just couldn’t memorize everything instantly. This constant back-and-forth completely breaks immersion, which is incredibly annoying.

Sure, I could watch a YouTube tutorial to understand the game better, but that’s not how I like to play. I prefer to learn by doing, and unfortunately, this game is terrible at teaching you the basics you need to play it properly.

Maybe the game simply isn’t beginner-friendly, and perhaps choosing it as my first space sim was a mistake.

But given these Points, I do not recommend it :S which is a Sad decision....

184750331.review:
People say it's a grind, but it's not that bad.  I'm exactly 100 hours in and I've done most aspects of the game.  I've completed all the Fed and Empire ranks to level 12, so I've unlocked all the ships.  I have around 15 ships (including the most expensive in the game - the Cutter).  I've done asteroid mining, transportation, explored outside the bubble, and I have 1.5 billion credits in the bank.  I've unlocked around 15-20 engineers and most of my ships are engineered to level 3 or 5 on fundamentals like FSD, shield generator, shield boosters, lasers, cannons, thrusters, power plant, etc.  I have enough materials and money that i will be able to go fully engineered on my next ship build - a combat Corvette.  Then I imagine i will go for a fleet ship or wait until system colonisation is released in 2025.  I'll eventually do both!

One top tip for money making - form a wing with friends and share your missions with one another once you are back at base.  You can make a mint doing that at easily 250 million per hour in a hazardous res zone with a 4 person wing team and half decent medium ships.  You can also make a quick 50 million doing a silver 400-500 units mining run missions.

As to the game, I love the realism of this over games like NMS, Star Citizen, Eve, etc.  And there is nothing like being the first person to discover an earth like planet and getting your name on it. :)

2. The fact that in the tutorial you face a ship with regeneration that constantly moves faster than your ship can turn to face it and hides behind obstacles that take a substantial amount of time to move around, and your weapons have limited ammo and have to reload often and are slow to reload. 
3. The fact that I paid money for a game that I will never play again because of lack of quality of life is painful.
I wanted to like it, but I can't even pass the tutorial due to intentional game design.

184650821.review: This is the most immersive space simulator on the market right now (not counting Star Citizen, which is an alpha product). Maybe the most immersive game period, but that is subjective. You can fly all across the galaxy, trade, mine, explore, fight, and build yourself up from nothing. It really feels like you are in space flying a space ship. This game does not help you much at all and there is a lot of learning, but after you learn the game it is peaceful and fun. In that way it is kind of like Euro Truck Simulator 2 or Microsoft Flight Simulator. I would recommend the game to anyone who doesn't mind learning a complex game and thinks the premise is intriguing. It definitely lives up to its promises of being able to fly a space ship and role play as a commander across the Milky Way Galaxy.
